content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find an article published between 1 January 2000 and 1 January 2005 that requires Support Vector Machines in the title and its Journey ref is ACL Workshop.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The task requires a search with the phrase "Support Vector Machines" in the title, filtered to articles published between 1 January 2000 and 1 January 2005, and whose journal reference contains "ACL Workshop." The main search box (label 4) is available and should be used. Next, advanced search options are likely needed to filter by date and journal reference. Clicking "Advanced Search" should provide those options.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for articles with "Support Vector Machines" in the title, use the search term input (label 12) and select "Title" in the dropdown (label 13). More filters will need to be added for date range and journal reference, likely by using "Add another term."
Action: Type [12]; Support Vector Machines
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current search yields articles with "Support Vector Machines" in the title but does not include filters for date range or journal reference. I need to add filters for the date (between 1 January 2000 and 1 January 2005) and journal reference (ACL Workshop). I should go back to "Refine query" to add these conditions.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current interface allows adding another search criterion—this is necessary to filter by Journal reference and by date. I should click "Add another term +" to introduce fields for the journal and/or publication date.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The new search row allows for another filtering condition. I need to switch the search field of the new row from "Title" to "Journal reference," and then enter "ACL Workshop" to filter by journal reference.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the field to search is open and "Journal reference" is visible in the list. I need to select "Journal reference" so that the next row can filter articles based on the Journal reference "ACL Workshop."
Action: Click [16] (on "Journal reference")
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for the new search term is still set to "Title" and needs to be changed to "Journal reference" to allow filtering based on the journal. I should select "Journal reference" from the dropdown.
Action: Click [16] (choose "Journal reference" option)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the search field is open, and "Journal reference" is listed as one of the available options. Selecting "Journal reference" will allow us to type "ACL Workshop" as required by the task.
Action: Click [16] (select "Journal reference" from the dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for the second search field is still open and "Journal reference" has not yet been selected. I need to select "Journal reference" to target the correct field in the query.
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" option)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the second search field is still open and "Journal reference" needs to be selected to allow input for "ACL Workshop" in the next step.
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" from dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown on the second search row is active, but "Journal reference" still hasn't been chosen. This must be done before inputting the required text ("ACL Workshop").
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" from the dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.72
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown on the second search row is open and "Journal reference" is visible. Selecting this will allow filtering by the required journal information in the next textbox.
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" in dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown under the second search field is currently displaying "Title," but I need to specifically select "Journal reference" from the dropdown so the next filter is set up correctly for "ACL Workshop."
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" from the dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.78
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for the second filter in advanced search is open, and "Journal reference" is visible as an option. It needs to be selected so we can enter "ACL Workshop" in the corresponding textbox.
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" from dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown under the second search field still shows the search category options. "Journal reference" needs to be selected so the corresponding filter can be applied for "ACL Workshop."
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" in the dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the second search criterion is still open, showing the available fields. "Journal reference" needs to be chosen here for entering "ACL Workshop" in the next step.
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" from dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.82
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu under the second search criterion is open and "Journal reference" is visible in the list. Selecting "Journal reference" here is required for the next step to filter articles by the journal ref "ACL Workshop."
Action: Click [16] ("Journal reference" in the dropdown)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.84

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: "Simple Search";	[12]: <input> "";	[13]: "TitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierCross-list categoryDOIORCIDarXiv author IDAll fields";	[14]: "ANDORNOT";	[15]: <input> "";	[16]: "TitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierCross-list categoryDOIORCIDarXiv author IDAll fields";	[17]: <button> "–", "Remove this search term";	[18]: <button> "Add another term +";	[19]: <button> "Search";	[25]: "allastro-phcond-matgr-qchep-exhep-lathep-phhep-thmath-phnlinnucl-exnucl-thphysicsquant-ph";

Action: Click [16] (select "Journal reference")
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.87
